properties.headline: Flood Warning issued February 10 at 10:00PM EST until February 11 at 6:00AM EST by NWS Charleston WV
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Charleston has issued a

* Flood Warning for Small Streams in...
Central Tyler County in northern West Virginia...

* Until 600 AM EST Tuesday.

* At 1000 PM EST, automated gauge data indicated water levels were
continuing to rise along the Middle Island Creek across Tyler
County, primarily from Middlebourne and areas to the west.
Flooding is ongoing near Middlebourne and is expected to occur
overnight for areas closer to Little.

* At 930 PM EST, the stage of Middle Island Creek near Middlebourne
was at 16.43 feet. The estimated flood stage is 16 feet. The creek
is expected to crest late this evening around 16.5 feet and then
slowly fall overnight. At stages near 16 feet, fields and low and
poor drainage areas along the creek and associated tributaries
begin to flood. In addition, the higher water levels should
continue downstream overnight and eventually cause the Middle
Island Creek at Little to rise above flood stage. At 930 PM EST,
the stage of Middle Island Creek at Little was 13.09 feet. The
estimated flood stage is 14 feet. The creek is expected to crest
late tonight around 14 feet and then slowly fall. At stages near
14 feet, the lower fields begin to flood and Stewarts Run Road
becomes flooded.

Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Middlebourne, Little, and other low and poor drainage areas along
and near Middle Island Creek.
properties.instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the
dangers of flooding.

Please report Severe Weather to the National Weather Service by
calling toll free, 800 401 9535, when you can do so safely. You may
also report severe weather by posting your report to the Charleston
West Virginia National Weather Service Facebook Page, or by using
the Twitter Hashtag, NWSRLX.
